title.narrative: GOVERNANCE FOR CHILDREN

description.narrative: The Ministry of Social Policy, in collaboration with relevant development partners, ensures a functioning governance system (including coordination, monitoring, reporting and follow-up) over the key institutional changes at national level that are needed to address outstanding CRC Recommendations 12, 14 and 18 (CRC/C/UKR/CO3-4)., which contributes to Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Human Rights Institutions, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Policy Advocacy â€“ Urban, Civil Society, Parliament, Environment, Social Exclusion â€“ Data And Evidence, Technical Excellence In Policy And Programmes. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Government of Ukraine is supported in its effort to reduce social exclusion and disparities at the national and sub-national levels.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: The Ministry of Social Policy, in collaboration with relevant development partners, ensures a functioning governance system(including coordination, monitoring, reporting and follow-up) over the key institutional changes at national level that are neededto address outstanding CRC Recommendations 12, 14 and 18 (CRC/C/UKR/CO3-4).
Number and significance of cross-sectoral child polices coordinated and endorsed by the Inter-ministerial Commission for Child Rights (or similar body)

baseline.value: 0 cross-sectoral child policies endorsed, there is no inter-ministerial coordination body for child policy (2011)

baseline.value: 2 percent funded from State Budget (or 17 million UAH), 98 percent unfunded (2010)
